lessons.title: Intro
lessons.interactiveContent: Most databases hold more than one table. So far, we've only selected data stored in a single table, like student here.

lessons.title: Intro 2
lessons.interactiveContent:
But what if the data we're looking for is stored over several tables? Like student and enrolled.

Tap on the table names.

lessons.title: Question 1
lessons.interactiveContent:
Before continuing, take a look at the two tables. What properties do they store?

student stores id and name, enrolled stores id and classenrolled stores id and name, student stores id and class

student stores id and name, enrolled stores id and class.

lessons.title: Intro 3
lessons.interactiveContent:
student links students' id to their name. enrolled connects a student's id to a class they enrolled for.

We're interested in the name of students that enrolled for each class.

lessons.title: Question 2
lessons.interactiveContent:
Before moving on, in which tables can we find the name and class properties?

We can find name in student and class in enrolledWe can find both name and class in the same table

We can find name in student and class in enrolled.

lessons.title: Joining tables
lessons.interactiveContent: To select properties from two tables, like name from student and the matching class from enrolled, we need to join the tables.

lessons.title: Joining tables 2
lessons.interactiveContent:
Joining tables means matching each row of the first table to a row in the second table based on a common property.

Code JOIN for a preview of the result.

Make sure to type JOIN.

lessons.title: Question: Joining tables 2
lessons.interactiveContent:
What does joining two tables mean?

Matching the two tables' rows based on a common propertyGluing the two tables together, regardless of whether the rows match or not

Matching the two tables' rows based on a common property.

lessons.title: Start with selecting
lessons.interactiveContent:
To join two tables, we start by selecting any one of them, like student here.

Make sure to pick SELECT * followed by FROM and then student, ;.

lessons.title: Join with the other table
lessons.interactiveContent:
We then merge it with the second table using JOIN and a table name, like enrolled.

Make sure to type JOIN enrolled.

lessons.title: Join on common property
lessons.interactiveContent:
For the corresponding class to each student's name, we join the tables based on a common property like id.

Make sure to pick id, followed by id.

lessons.title: The ON keyword
lessons.interactiveContent:
The keyword ON introduces a condition that decides whether a row from student should match a row from enrolled.

Make sure to type ON.

lessons.title: Condition
lessons.interactiveContent:
With the student's id as the common property, rows only match if the id in student matches that in enrolled.

Make sure to pick student.id =, followed by enrolled.id.

lessons.title: Access a property
lessons.interactiveContent:
Notice that to access a table's property, we code the table, a full stop ., and the property name. Like here with student.id.

Make sure to type student.id.

lessons.title: Question: Join with the other table
lessons.interactiveContent:
Which keyword do we use to join two tables?

JOINMERGE

Make sure to pick JOIN.

lessons.title: Question: Join on common property
lessons.interactiveContent:
What's the common property of these two tables?

artist_idname

Make sure to pick artist_id.

lessons.title: Question: The ON keyword
lessons.interactiveContent:
How do we introduce a condition for joining the tables?

With the ON keywordWith the WHERE keyword

With the ON keyword.

lessons.title: Question: Condition
lessons.interactiveContent:
Which condition should we choose to match an artist's name to an album's title?

artist.artist_id = album.artist_idartist.artist_id <> album.artist_id

artist.artist_id = album.artist_id.

lessons.title: Question: Access a property
lessons.interactiveContent:
How do we access the name property of an artist table?

With artist.nameWith name.artist

With artist.name.

lessons.title: Example: Start with selecting
lessons.interactiveContent:
Select all items from the artist table.

Make sure to pick SELECT followed by * and then FROM, artist, ;.

lessons.title: Example: Join with the other table
lessons.interactiveContent:
Select joined rows from the artist and album tables by adding JOIN album.

Make sure to type JOIN album.

lessons.title: Example: The ON keyword
lessons.interactiveContent:
Code ON to introduce a condition for joining the tables.

Make sure to type ON.

lessons.title: Example: Condition
lessons.interactiveContent:
Write a condition to join rows only if the artist.artist_id equals album.artist_id.

Make sure to pick . followed by artist_id and then =, album, ., artist_id.

lessons.title: Example: Access a property
lessons.interactiveContent:
Access the artist table's artist_id property with artist.artist_id.

Make sure to type artist.artist_id.

lessons.title: Inner JOIN
lessons.interactiveContent: We can represent the two tables' id values through circles. The colored inner part is for common id values.

lessons.title: Inner JOIN 2
lessons.interactiveContent: JOIN is short for INNER JOIN because it only selects those rows with a common value in a specific column like id.

lessons.title: Connecting rows
lessons.interactiveContent:
INNER JOIN uses a common property like id to connect corresponding rows from the two tables in one result table.

Make sure to type INNER JOIN.

lessons.title: Missing row
lessons.interactiveContent:
0267, Lin Wong from students won't appear in the results. That's because there's no id value 0267 in the enrolled table.

Make sure to pick = followed by enrolled and then ., id.

lessons.title: No matching value
lessons.interactiveContent:
With INNER JOIN, rows without a matching value in the common column don't appear in the results.

Make sure to pick INNER JOIN followed by enrolled and then ON, student.id = enrolled.id.

lessons.title: Question: Inner JOIN 2
lessons.interactiveContent:
What's the difference between JOIN and INNER JOIN?

There's no difference, JOIN is short for INNER JOINJOIN connects rows whether they match or not

There's no difference, JOIN is short for INNER JOIN.

lessons.title: Question: Missing row
lessons.interactiveContent:
Which artist item won't appear in the query results?

3, Bill Evans because there is no artist_id equal to 3 in albums1, John Coltrane because it has two matches

3, Bill Evans because there is no artist_id equal to 3 in albums.

lessons.title: Question: No matching value
lessons.interactiveContent:
What does INNER JOIN do when rows don't have a matching value in the other table?

It doesn't join them, so they won't appear in the resultsIt joins them to a randomly picked row

It doesn't join them, so they won't appear in the results.

lessons.title: Example: Missing row
lessons.interactiveContent:
Code a condition to only join rows that have a matching artist_id in the other table.

Make sure to pick ON artist.artist_id followed by = and then album, ., artist_id.

lessons.title: Example: No matching value
lessons.interactiveContent:
Write a query to join artist and album on the common property artist_id. Notice that 3, Bill Evans won't appear in the results.

Make sure to pick INNER JOIN album followed by ON artist.artist_id and then =, album.artist_id.

lessons.title: Two matching values
lessons.interactiveContent:
Let's look at what happens with multiple matches.

We've added one more row to enrolled. The id value 1008 is now enrolled in two classes.

lessons.title: Two matching values 2
lessons.interactiveContent:
The item 1008, Luz Garcia from students now has two matches in enrolled, because of the duplicate 1008.

Make sure to pick FROM student followed by INNER and then JOIN, enrolled.

lessons.title: Two matching values 3
lessons.interactiveContent:
Rows with multiple matches appear in the result table once for each match. Like 1008, Luz Garcia showing up twice.

Make sure to pick ON followed by student and then ., id, = enrolled.id.

lessons.title: Question: Two matching values 2
lessons.interactiveContent:
Which item from artist has multiple matches in the album table?

1, John Coltrane since there are two albums having 1 as the artist_id2, Nina Simone since there are two albums having 2 as the artist_id

1, John Coltrane since there are two albums having 1 as the artist_id.

lessons.title: Question: Two matching values 3
lessons.interactiveContent:
What happens when a row from one table matches multiple rows in the other?

The row will appear multiple times in the result table, once for each matchThe row will only be matched with one of the rows in the other table

The row will appear multiple times in the result table, once for each match.

lessons.title: Question: Two matching values 3.1
lessons.interactiveContent:
How many times will John Coltrane appear in the result table?

Twice, because it matches two album itemsOnce, because a value can only appear once

Twice, because it matches two album items.

lessons.title: Example: Two matching values 2
lessons.interactiveContent:
Select all items when joining the artist and album tables, and notice that 1, John Coltrane appears twice in the results.

Make sure to pick SELECT * followed by FROM artist and then INNER, JOIN, album.
